comments.content: Comptia won't tell you what exact answers you got correct or wrong. At the end of your exam you'll receive a paper with your results and basically a summary of the topics you got wrong. It's categorized as the objectives on the website (ex. "5.3 Given a scenario, troubleshoot and diagnose problems with drives and RAID arrays"). But it doesn't tell you what exact questions you got wrong or the amount of questions you get wrong. you just get a score and a summary. Hope this helps if you haven't taken your test yet.
Did they tell you what the answer was at the end?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
This minimizes interference between the access points, ensuring better performance and lower latency.

Selected Answer: D
Configuring a Wi-Fi network with different channels pointing to the same SSID avoids interference which will in turn avoid latency.

Selected Answer: A
Enabling and configuring a 5GHz antenna (A) can help avoid high latency in a SOHO (Small Office/Home Office) wireless solution. The 5GHz frequency band typically has less interference compared to the 2.4GHz band, which can lead to improved performance and reduced latency.

comments.content: But if you config the three APs in different channels, how could you roam automatically in the SOHO network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Configuring all devices with different channels would avoid high latency in this scenario. By configuring the access points with different channels, they would not interfere with each other and reduce latency. Enabling and configuring a 5GHz antenna would help to avoid interference, but it might not be enough in a SOHO environment where multiple access points are in use. Configuring separate IP ranges and enabling multiple SSIDs are not directly related to reducing latency.

questions.question_text: A technician is implementing a SOHO wireless solution with three access points. Which of the following actions would avoid high latency?

choices.D: Configuring all devices with different channels

The minimum cable category that could be used to support a 10Gbps throughput is Cat 6a. Cat 6a cable is required with 10 Gigabit Ethernet for reliable performance with cable lengths up to 100 metres. However, lower-specification cables can often be successfully used, particularly with the shorter cable lengths required in a typical home123.

choices.A:
For a software developer who is required to test an application in many environments
В. When the data center environment is out of resources for a new server
choices.C: To provide a backup to cloud-based solutions during internet failures
choices.B: As a cost-saving measure to allow multiple users on one computer

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes the BEST use case for a client-side hypervisor?

comments.content: To make confusing question more confusing

discussion.content: Why are "A" and "B" Selected at the same time?

Selected Answer: A
A. For a software developer who is required to test an application in many environments.

A client-side hypervisor is a type of software that allows a single computer to run multiple virtual machines (VMs) simultaneously, each with its own operating system and applications. This technology is useful for software developers who need to test their applications in different environments, as they can create multiple VMs that mimic different operating systems, browsers, and configurations. The developer can then run their application on each of these VMs to ensure that it works properly in all environments. This saves time and resources compared to setting up separate physical machines for each environment.

Selected Answer: A
A client-side hypervisor is used to run multiple virtual machines (VMs) on a single workstation or computer. It allows a user to test or operate various operating systems and environments simultaneously on their local machine. This makes it an ideal solution for software developers who need to:

Test applications across different operating systems and configurations.
Debug or verify compatibility in isolated environments.
Its A. Absolutly 100%. YOu use Virtual Pc's to test software. Multiple OS's on the same physical host machine.

which of the answers is more accurate? 
I thought B is the correct and more logical but came to the discussion to gain confusion (

comments.content: this comment made me giggle. It is also very relatable lol

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
"Client-side virtualization refers to any solution designed to run on "ordinary" desktops or workstations. Each user will be interacting with the virtualization host directly. Desktop virtual platforms, usually based on some sort of guest OS hypervisor, are typically used for TESTING AND DEVELOPMENT." CompTIA Learn CertMaster

Selected Answer: A
Per Professor Messer - "Client-side virtualization provides a way to run many different operating systems on the same desktop. In this video, you’ll learn about the resource requirements and network configurations for client-side virtualization."

Selected Answer: C
Pay attention to the words in the question, it says nothing about redundancy. Only answer what the question is actually asking, which is cost-effective. RAID 10 is not cost-effective, due to really only using 50% of the disks' storage capacity.

comments.content: This question was on my exam and I didn't miss anything in this particular objective, so I'm sure the answer is 15,000rpm HDD.
In the question, also said Cost Effective. So RAID 10 is not the answer
There is nothing that mentions redundancy plus RAID is not a type of storage device. It is how the drives are to be used by the system to create redundancy or performance use of the drives you have
RAID 10 fails the "cost-effective" part of this question and it does not mention redundancy or fault tolerance. Just cost.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A RAID 10 array is a redundant array of independent disks that combines the features of both RAID 1 (mirroring) and RAID 0 (striping). This configuration provides both data redundancy and improved read/write performance.

By using a RAID 10 array, the VM host can have a cost-effective and reliable storage solution for all VMs that run from the server. The performance of the RAID 10 array can be optimized by selecting the appropriate type of hard drives, such as 7,200rpm or 10,000rpm drives, which are typically less expensive than 15,000rpm drives.

Selected Answer: C
I asked ChatGPT first its said D but when i asked why comptia says C this is the answer:
You're right to lean toward D (RAID 10) from a practical, sysadmin or enterprise perspective.

But CompTIA wants you to choose C in the context of:

Lower budget

Single drive setup
Basic understanding of VM host requirements

Selected Answer: D
While a 15000rpm drive would be less expensive in dollars, the RAID 10 array provides redundancy. If the "storage will be used for all VMs that run from the server" you need to factor in the cost of losing all the VMs WHEN that single 15k drive fails. A and B are outliers that can easily be eliminated.

Selected Answer: D
D. RAID 10 array.

A RAID 10 array provides a good balance of speed, redundancy, and reliability, making it ideal for hosting multiple virtual machines (VMs). It combines the benefits of RAID 1 (mirroring) for redundancy and RAID 0 (striping) for performance, which is important for the intensive read/write operations required by VMs.
Aren't A and C kind of the same answer? rpm is the speed of which the spindel turns at on a HDD. An HDD is an optical drive. I'm a bit confused by this.

comments.content: nah, optical drives are CD players, DVD players, and blueray players. HDD got the spinny disk thing but isnt what is meant by optical drive.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The question asks for cost-effectiveness, not redundancy, efficiency, fault tolerance or availability. 

So RAID 10 would be wildly wrong as that would be the most expensive option there with 4 or more drives.

The best storage device for a rackmount server that will be used as a VM host and will be used for all VMs that run from the server would be a RAID 10 array. RAID 10 is a combination of RAID 1 and RAID 0, which provides both redundancy and performance. It requires at least four disks and provides high read and write speeds, as well as fault tolerance. This makes it an ideal choice for a VM host.

An optical disk drive is not a suitable option for this scenario, as it is not designed for use as a storage device for VMs.

An eMMC storage device is a type of flash storage that is commonly used in mobile devices. It is not designed for use as a storage device for VMs, as it has limited capacity and performance.

A 15,000rpm drive is a type of hard disk drive that provides high performance. However, it is not the best option for a VM host, as it does not provide redundancy

Selected Answer: C
"Cost effective" and nothing about redundancy so D is not the answer
There is nothing mentioned about redundancy (RAID), so it has to be 15,000 rpm

Selected Answer: C
eMMC is a storage used by portable devices like cell phones or tablets. The optical disk drive is the primary use for the archive of data, documents, movies, etc. The question states cost-effective and does not mention anything about a backup. You can back up your data directly into the cloud also. If it is only about money then option C would be right in that situation. However, RAID 10 is a more expensive solution and better at the same time.
A device that will install into a server is a hard drive so the answer should be C: 15,000rpm drive

Selected Answer: D
D. RAID 10 array.

A RAID (redundant array of independent disks) 10 array provides both performance and data redundancy, making it a good choice for a VM host. RAID 10 combines the mirroring of RAID 1 with the striping of RAID 0, which provides faster read and write speeds. Additionally, it provides redundancy by using at least four disks to create two mirrored sets of striped drives. This means that if one disk fails, the data is still available on the mirrored disk. Optical disk drives are not suitable for storage of VMs. eMMC storage devices are small, inexpensive storage devices often used in tablets and smartphones, but are not typically used in servers. 15,000rpm drives provide fast read and write speeds, but they are not redundant, so they do not provide data protection in case of a drive failure.

comments.content: You can back up your data into the clouds directly. If that would be my choice I would go with RAID 10; Because it is a server and if one drive fails you have a backup right away. Cloud backup is a bit more hustle and you have to pay for that also. Just the question is made the way that fits option C more and that is not the best option. CompTIA weird :)
